snippet: President Obama surprised aides last year when he called the use of chemical weapons in Syria a “red line,” a move that has complicated the American response to evidence that such arms have been used.
abstract: Pres Obama surprised aides in August 2012 when he called use of chemical weapons in Syria a 'red line,' move that complicates American response to evidence that such arms have been used; Obama now confronts most urgent foreign policy issue of his second term, one in which he must weigh humanitarian impulses against risk to American lives.

byline.original: By PETER BAKER, MARK LANDLER, DAVID E. SANGER and ANNE BARNARD
byline.contributor: Peter Baker, Mark Landler and David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: President Obama surprised aides last year when he called the use of chemical weapons in Syria a “red line,” a move that has complicated the American response to evidence that such arms have been used.

headline.seo: Obama’s Vow on Chemical Weapons Puts Him in Tough Spot
